articles.headline: Out of Race, Karzai Rival Is Harsh Critic of Election
articles.snippet: Abdullah Abdullah announced that he would not participate in the Afghan runoff election, effectively handing a new term to President Hamid Karzai.
articles.abstract: Abdullah Abdullah announced that he would not participate in the Afghan runoff election, effectively handing a new term to President Hamid Karzai.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s last presidential challenger, Abdullah Abdullah, dropped out of the race on Sunday, accusing the government of profound corruption and electoral fraud even as the Obama administration rallied around President Hamid Karzai.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Business Is a Beat Deflated
articles.snippet: So you might expect the business press to be striking up the band and restocking the cigar cabinet. But the business of covering business may never really come back.
articles.abstract: So you might expect the business press to be striking up the band and restocking the cigar cabinet. But the business of covering business may never really come back.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country may be seeing a light at the end of the tunnel that isn’t another oncoming train.

articles.headline: Small Banks Move In as Giants Falter
articles.snippet: Small independent banks are joining together with a simple message: You can trust us -- we didn’t cause the crisis and didn’t need bailouts.
articles.abstract: Small independent banks are joining together with a simple message: You can trust us -- we didn’t cause the crisis and didn’t need bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Texas banker Edward Speed wants his fellow Texans to think small.

articles.headline: DVR, Once TV’s Mortal Foe, Helps Ratings
articles.snippet: Once feared as commercial killers, the recorders now add significantly to program ratings and thus to ad revenue.
articles.abstract: Once feared as commercial killers, the recorders now add significantly to program ratings and thus to ad revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what may seem a media business version of the Stockholm syndrome, television network executives have fallen in love with a former tormentor: the digital video recorder.

articles.headline: Creditors Back CIT’s Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: CIT entered a different kind of bankruptcy that will let it reemerge from court protection by the end of the year under the ownership of its creditors.
articles.abstract: CIT entered a different kind of bankruptcy that will let it reemerge from court protection by the end of the year under the ownership of its creditors.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the CIT Group sought desperately to avoid bankruptcy this summer, it argued that being forced into Chapter 11 protection would spell disaster for its customers: a wide swath of the nation’s small and midsize businesses who rely on the 101-year-old company for financing.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: With Karzai, U.S. Faces Weak Partner in Time of War
articles.snippet: After Abdullah Abdullah’s withdrawal from the Afghan runoff, President Obama faces the challenge of enabling President Hamid Karzai to regain enough legitimacy to help with the war.
articles.abstract: After Abdullah Abdullah’s withdrawal from the Afghan runoff, President Obama faces the challenge of enabling President Hamid Karzai to regain enough legitimacy to help with the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the White House’s reluctant embrace on Sunday of Hamid Karzai as the winner of Afghanistan’s suddenly moot presidential runoff, President Obama now faces a new complication: enabling a badly tarnished partner to regain enough legitimacy to help the United States find the way out of an eight-year-old war.

articles.headline: When Texting Kills, Britain Offers Path to Prison
articles.snippet: Britain has become aggressive in cracking down on the use of cellphones while driving.
articles.abstract: Britain has become aggressive in cracking down on the use of cellphones while driving.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England  Inside the imposing British Crown Court here, Phillipa Curtis, 22, and her parents cried as she was remanded for 21 months to a high-security women’s prison, for killing someone much like herself. The victim was Victoria McBryde, an up-and-coming university-trained fashion designer.

articles.headline: For Galleon Executive, Swagger in the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Both the insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam and the man himself are more complex than they seem.
articles.abstract: Both the insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam and the man himself are more complex than they seem.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire hedge fund manager charged with trading on inside information, legal problems are nothing new.

articles.headline: Lupus Drug Shows Promise in New Trial
articles.snippet: Human Genome Sciences said early Monday that its experimental drug to treat lupus was effective in its second big clinical trial.
articles.abstract: Human Genome Sciences said early Monday that its experimental drug to treat lupus was effective in its second big clinical trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debilitating disease called lupus has been a graveyard for pharmaceutical companies in recent years. One drug after another has had setbacks or outright failures in clinical trials.

articles.headline: Obama Warns Karzai to Focus on Tackling Corruption
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, now assured of a new term, was urged by President Obama “to write a new chapter” in his government’s legitimacy.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, now assured of a new term, was urged by President Obama “to write a new chapter” in his government’s legitimacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday admonished President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan that he must take on what American officials have said he avoided during his first term: the rampant corruption and drug trade that have fueled the resurgence of the Taliban.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Ford Posts an Unexpected Profit of $997 Million
articles.snippet: The Ford Motor Company had its first profitable quarter in North America in over four years and said that, at least for now, it had stopped rapidly burning through its cash reserves.
articles.abstract: The Ford Motor Company had its first profitable quarter in North America in over four years and said that, at least for now, it had stopped rapidly burning through its cash reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  While its crosstown rivals stumbled through bankruptcy this summer, the Ford Motor Company pressed its advantage, and delivered surprising news on Monday that its cost-cutting efforts and improving sales helped it earn nearly $1 billion in the third quarter.
